LIMA, June 15.--Important and disastrous news has been received from the south. On the morning of May 26 the Chilian Army attacked the advanced posts of the allied troops, and drove them in upon the main body, intrenched in the neighborhood of the City of Tacna. The Chilians numbered 18,000 men of all arms, and had 42 pieces of artillery, principally Krupp and Armstrong, with 50 Gatling batteries, and were commanded by Gen. Baquedano.

LONDON, July 16.--In Mincing-lane this week there has been no decided change, but the markets appear more settled than at the close of the previous week. Sugar has been steady. West Indies was generally firmer. Refined advanced 6d., but low brown sorts are unimproved.

DENVER, Col., July 15.--Advices from along the Kansas Pacific Railroad say the region was visited by a heavy storm, extending from Mirage to Cedar Point. At Hugo the people had to ascend the roofs for safety. While a freight train of 11 cars was crossing the bridge at Hugo 10 of the cars were washed away. No lives were lost.

YEAST.--One pint mashed potatoes, water and all, one cup of flour, one cup of sugar, one cup of salt, one cup strong hop tea, four quarts boiling water. When nearly cool add a pint of good yeast. SARATOGA, July 21.--This has been another successful day for the Saratoga Racing Association. The weather was delightful, the track in fine condition, and the attendance of spectators very large. NEWBURG, N.Y., July 21.--Mary Isabella, 22 years of age, daughter of Samuel McQuaid, residing at Coldenham, six miles west of this city, attempted to light a fire with kerosene, yesterday afternoon, when the can of oil exploded, and she was fatally burned. LONDON, Aug. 2.--A Vienna correspondent says the statement that the Porte intends to cede Dulcigno to Montenegro is strengthened by the dispatch of a Turkish naval squadron to the Dulcigno coast to enforce the cession.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 1.--John McTague, a boy 15 years old, had his carotid artery cut on July 5 by a stray bullet. Last Thursday secondary hemorrhage set in. To-day he was subjected to a surgical operation at the Cincinati Hospital, and died under the knife on the surgeon's table.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 1.--W.K. Boone, of Allen County, was unanimously nominated Republican candidate for Congress for the Fifth Ohio District, at Lima, yesterday.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 1.--Samuel George, Jr., 31 years of age, a prominent citizen, died to-day after a lingering illness. He was President of the Farmers' and Mechanics' Bank, and was said to be the youngest bank President in the United States.

DENVER, Col., Aug. 1.--The joint track of the Denver and South Park and Denver and Rio Grande Railroads was completed into Leadville yesterday, and both companies be gan running regular through trains to-day. Their track is also completed and opened for business to Hortense, 12 miles from Buena Vista, on the Gunnison extension.

FIRE ISLAND, Aug. 1.--There certainly cannot be much significance in a name when Fire Island stands for the coolest place within a hundred miles of New-York. The first inquiry of every new-comer is, How did it ever get this, lying cognomen? The "oldest inhabitant" will hardly be able to answer the question satisfactorily.

In the August number of the North American Review the editor, Mr. Allen Thorndike Rice, who has taken part in organizing the expedition, gives an account of its plan and aims.

SIMLA, Aug. 1.--Reports from Quettahindicate that Ayoob Khan did not follow up his victory by pursuing the British. It is stated that Gen. Burrows succeeded in bringing a large body of his troops into Kandahar.

HAMMERFEST, July 2.--Here we are once more in the "northernmost town of Europe," on our way back from the North Cape. It is difficult to imagine anything more primitive than this quaint little cluster of painted wooden shanties pasted along the base of a huge precipitous mountain, which here forms a deep angular hollow, as if to shelter its tiny guest.

A very large and influential deputation, consisting of members of cattle-trade associations of the midland counties and north of England, had an interview with Earl Spencer and Mr. Mundella, at the Privy Council Office, on July 19, to urge upon the Government the desirability of taking off the restrictions imposed by the late Government on cattle imported from abroad, and from America particularly.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1.--Michael Mackin was shot and fatally wounded at noon to-day by his brother William, while trying to enter the house of the latter. William, who is an industrious working man, lives, with his wife, at No. 3,515 Loweavenue. SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 1.--Max Burckhardt, editor and propietor of the Humorist a German weekly, committed suicide by taking morphine. The cause of the act is unknown. He was a native of Berlin and about 50 years of age.

E.H. Crosby's team. Capt. Old was presented at the close of the contest with a handsome floral gift.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Aug. 1.--Capt. Wrecken, of the schooner Winnifred, which arrived at Canso from the Banks yesterday, reports that when about 40 miles from Cape Canso a large brigantine came so near to running him down that they could have jumped on board of her. Every person is on good terms with his neighbors, and all join in the wish for the heated term to come to a close.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 4.--The severest storm of the season visited this place to-day. DENVER, Col., Aug. 7.--An old man named Matthew Dowling, living on Cubb Creek, 22 miles south-west of Golden, hanged himself in his cellar yesterday. Domestic troubles were the cause of the act.

Ex-Gov. William Bigler, of Pennsylvania, died at his home in Clearfield yesterday morning at 9 o'clock. For a number of years he had been affected with valvular disease of the heart, and for the last 12 months greatly enfeebled. For the last three months he had been confined to his room.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 11.--Charles H. Tandy, President of the Colored Relief Board of this city, has advices that 10,000 negroes will emigrate from Mississippi and Louisiana within the next two months and will arrive here, en route to Kansas and other Northern States. GALVESTON, Aug. 11.--A special to the News, from Dallas, says: "The Democratic State Convention, to-day, renominated Gov. O. M. Roberts on the first ballot, and L.J. Storey for Lieutenant-Governor by acclamation."

CHICAGO, Aug. 11.--Alvin Dexterevert, 60 years old, committed suicide this morning by taking laudanum. The act is said to have been caused by a refusal of admission to the house of his sister-inlaw. An examination of his body disclosed a bullet-hole under the left breast, and a scar on the back where the ball had passed out. The wounds, which are partially healed, are thought to be two days' old.

MITCHELL POINT, N.J., April 11.--Eusebius Jeninng, a married man, 23 years old, was drowned while bathing this morning. He went out upon the bay in a boat with his newly married wife, and went in swimming. He was seized with cramps, and sank before the eyes of his agonized wife. His cries were heard from the shore, but too late to bring assistance.

SALT LAKE, Utah, Aug. 11.--The Mormon Returning Board of Beaver County have thrown out the vote of the Gentile precincts of Frisco, Milford, Adamsville, and Minersville, defeating the State Sheriff-elect on the Liberal ticket. NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 11.--The steam-boat Bonnie Lee, hence Saturday for Red River, with 250 tons of assorted merchandise, blew up and sank on Monday evening at Lonewall Landing. ALBANY, Aug. 11.--For several years past the village of Schagticoke, Rensselaer County, has been annually visited by malignant diphtheria, causing hundreds of deaths. The first epidemic occurred as far back as 1874. The cause of the scourge has at last been discovered.

The willow which overshadows the first Bonaparte's grave is the second planted since the interment of the Emperor, and is 26 years old. Willows at St. Helena, it would appear, rarely attain a greater longevity than 30 years, and shoots are carefully preserved for planting.
BOSTON, Aug. 12.--The Portuguese bark Surpreza, Capt. Ribeiro, hence Aug. 10, for Demarara with a cargo of ice, returned here to-day.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 12.--Special Agent Sawyer, of the Census Bureau, completed his labor of revising the work of the census enumerators here this afternoon, and left to-night for Louisville, where he will perform a similar work. He makes the population of St. Louis 333,577.

GRANVILLE, N.J., Aug. 12.--The body of Eusebius Jennings, who was drowned near Mitchell's Point yesterday afternoon, was found by Jerome Hop, a fisherman, at High Dock, this morning. The deceased and wife were but recently married, and were residents of Boston.

The Yonkers Yacht Club had what they termed a "ladies' race" yesterday afternoon on the Hudson off Yonkers. The race was so called because a lady was carried aboard each yacht, and was designated, for the time being, its Captain.

A house at Manhasset, Long Island, recently owned and occupied by Milton Smith, was built by his father, Richard R. Smith, in 1835. At his father's death Milton fell heir to the property. Recently he mortgaged the place to parties in NewYork, and not being able to pay the interest, was dispossessed.

Atkinson, 41; S.H. Clemens, 38; E.F. Chamberlain, 38; G.L. Breck, 31; George B. Thompson, 29. In the Remington match, 200 yards, the best scores were; E. Oram, 45; M. Reese, of Dobb's Ferry, N.Y. and the Rev. Arthur Lawrence officiating. Ex-Lieut.-Gov. Doraheimer, of New-York, was a pall-bearer.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12.--Returns from the elections for county officers in East Tennessee, held last week, have been received here, and they show very satisfactory Republican gains.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12.--A special dispatch to the Tribune from Indianapolis, Ind., says: "Godfried Allentz, a German gardener, living near this city, locked himself in an upper room of his house yesterday afternoon and set fire to the building. The excursion barge Republic was floated off Flood Rock shortly before 12 o'clock Wednesday night. She had received no injury, and yesterday was towed to Oriental Grove with another party of excursionists.

TRENTON, Aug. 12.--Mrs. Anna Maria Sutterly committed suicide this morning, at her residence, in this city, hanging herself from the banisters of the attic. BATAVIA, Aug. 13.--The Republicans of Genesee County are a unit. We have yet to hear of a single Republican who will vote for Hancock, while it is claimed that there are a few Democrats who announce their intention to support Garfield.

NORWICH, Aug. 11.--The campaign work in this county is proceeding satisfactorily, and is, I believe, in very much better condition than it was four years ago at this time. This is an agricultural county, and, of course, the harvest now occupies the attention of the mass of the people. Still, in almost every section of the county, the preparatory work is going on prosperously.

Every Republican one meets seems to be zealous for success. This does not refer to politicians, but to men of all classes, including business men, professional men, working men, and farmers.

WHITBY, Ontario, Aug. 15.--Capt. Sherwood, of the steamer Norseman, which plies between Port Hope and Rochester, N.Y., died this morning from the effects of morphine, given by a druggist's clerk in mistake for quinine, called for by a prescription.
BREWSTERS, Aug. 13.--There is a most gratifying feeling of satisfaction among all the Republicans of Putnam County.

HOMER, Aug. 13.--The political situation in Cortland County is beginning to be interesting. Republican campaign clubs have already been formed in nearly every town, and the number of voters joining them indicates an unusual interest.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 15.--George Rackers, an old man, was killed this morning by Herman Rackers, his son, in Dayton, Ky., opposite the eastern portion of Cincinnati. Rackers had been melancholy for some time over the loss of money deposited with Archbishop Purcell, and also over the loss of trust funds deposited with the bankrupt St. Francis's Church, of Dayton, Ky.

A handsome writing-table has been made at the command of the Queen out of a portion of the timber of the old Arctic ship Repulse, which was lately broken up. Her Majesty intends to present it to the President of the United States "as a memorial of the courtesy and loving kindness which dictated the offer of the Resolute." It will, of course, be placed in the White House.

TROY, Aug. 13.--Political affairs in this vicinity are quiet. The Republicans have not begun operations, while all that has been done on the Democratic side has been the organization of Hancock and English campaign clubs in nearly all the wards of Troy and in some of the towns of Rensselaer County.

DANSVILLE, Aug. 13.--In 1860, with a total vote of 8,439 in Livingston County, the Republican majority was 1,917; in 1864, with a total of 8,133, the Republican majority was 1,027; in 1868, with a total of 8,288, the Republican majority was 1,358; in 1872, with a total of 8,102, the Republican majority was 1,404; in 1876, with a total of 9,540, the Republican plurality was 1,023, and Republican majority 994.
NYACK, Aug. 13.--A careful consideration of the political situation in Rockland County shows results highly favorable to the Republican Party-- much more so than four years ago.

Capt. Wheeler, of the ship General McClellan, which arrived from San Francisco yesterday, reports the loss of one of his crew during the passage.

HERKIMER, Aug. 13.--I have taken considerable pains to ascertain, both by observation and inquiry, how the nominations of the two parties are received by the voters of this county. LONDON, Aug. 22.--Lloyds' agent at St.Vincent telegraphs, under date of 21st inst., that one of the missing boats, containing seven men and five bags of mail-matter from the steamer American, of the Cape of Good Hope and Southampton Line, which foundered on April 28, near the equator, was picked up by the Portugese brig Tarujo, and the men and mails landed at Loanda, Africa, ou July 11.

For several weeks past a junk-dealer named Thomas Holmes, and a laborer named Patrick Dinan, both living in South Brooklyn, have been making arrangements for a prizefight. The men are leader's of two rival gangs of the roughs who infest that locality, and the fight was to decide which deserved the title of "the better man."

Probably few persons have had so many proposals of marriage as Lady Burdett-Coutts. I was talking a day or two ago with an eminent widower. "I myself," he said, "have proposed to her, for I regard this as a duty that every man owes to his family,"
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 22.--Owen Welsh, 15 years old, died at the Episcopal Hospital early this morning from injuries received in the railroad collision at May's Landing.

The prediction made a week ago that the receipts here of Delaware peaches during the week to follow would be very little in excess of one-half the quantity received the previous week has been verified. There was received during the past week about 350 car-loads, against 650 for the previous week.

SIMLA, Aug. 22.--It is reported from Quettah that the Kandahar garrison has made a sortie, inflicting heavy losses on the Heratees. The number of British casualties is unknown. It is believed that the tribes north of the Khojak Pass have collected to attack the communications with Pishin.
OCEAN GROVE, N.J., Aug. 22.--The first Sunday camp-meeting day of the season attracted the greatest crowd of people that has ever assembled at one time in Ocean Grove.

The merchants of this City, in general, seem to be favorable to the project of holding the World's Fair here in 1883, although there may be found occasionally a man who is either indifferent or opposed to the undertaking.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 23.--A fire at an early hour this morning destroyed the paper warehouse of Averill, Russel Carpenter, in lower Third-street, occupying two buildings, and a wholesale grocery of P.H. Kelly Co., adjoining. The fire spread with great rapidity, and it is feared that one man was killed by the falling walls of Kelly's house, which fell into the street without warning.
The Jamesport camp-meeting was opened yesterday. John C. Jones, a prominent citizen and large oyster-planter of Port Washington, has been missing for several days.
The Republicans of Iowa are confident that they will carry the State for Garfield and Arthur by a majority of not less than 65,000.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23.--A strange story is told of disgraceful proceedings in the Capitol, and of an unwillingmess on the part of those in charge of the building to punish the guilty person. During the sessions of Congress a little store for the sale of newspapers, pamphlets, , is kept by a gentleman and his wife in the main corridor, near the entrance to the chamber of the House of Representatives.

The Republicans are alive and moving in Lancaster County, Penn. A correspondent of the National Committee, writing from Ephrata, says: "No defection in our ranks here in the northern section. The old guard is organized with stalwarts to the front. Each township has its club. Put us down safe for our full quota, and a little to spare, of the 9,000 majority of Lancaster County.

If the story told by the conductor and driver of car No. 141 of the Third-avenue line of horse cars is true, one of the boldest outrages ever perpetrated by the criminal classes of this City was committed on Sunday morning. The car reached Houston-street at about 4 o'clock on its way down town, in charge of Conductor Louis Marks, and driven by Charles Parker.

An ice-water fountain erected at Five Points by the Moderation Society was formally opened yesterday. The Garfield and Arthur Club of the Thirteenth Assembly District will hold a ratification meeting this evening.

The body of Major-Gen. Joseph B. Kiddoo was removed early yesterday morning from the late residence of the deceased, and deposited in the vestibule of Trinity Chapel an hour before the beginning of the funeral services. It reposed in a richly mounted coffin, and was attired in the uniform of a General.

The Irish-American Republican Association met last evening at No. 119 Nassau-street, Mr. John C. Hennessy presiding. Several speakers addressed the meeting, including Gen. Millen, Counselors McCabe and Nolan, Messrs. Mitchell, Landrigan, and...

SARATOGA, Aug. 23.--The third meeting of the Saratoga Association, which is to continue through the week, was auspiciously opened to-day, the weather being delightful and the racing fairly good, although the fields were small in each of the events. The favorites were beaten in three of the races, and, consequently, there was a great deal of excitement, especially in the steeple-chase, in which Wayfarer defeated Reed's pair of steeple-chasers, ...

The transfer of PAYNE, the Indian Territory raider, from military to civil custody betokens a legal proceeding in which the whole question of the status of the Territory will be opened. Gen. POPE long ago took the ground that PAYNE desired to be arrested, not so much for the sake of notoriety as for testing the power of the laws to punish him.
The body of a female child about a year old was found yesterday tied up in a bag and floating in the Fulton Ferry slip. The remains were sent to the Morgue.

LONDON, Aug. 23.--The London correspondent of a provincial paper states that the greater part of Miss Neilson's property, which is estimated at about 40,000, is left by will to Rear-Admiral Henry Carr Glyn, C.B., and Mr. Edward Compton received a legacy of 1,000.
Job Compton, aged 19 Years, was seized with cramps while bathing at Port Monmouth Sunday evening, and was drowned.

THE CATSKILLS, Aug. 16--The traveler who comes to the Catskills, provided he has not sated himself with the Alps, the Apennines, and the Himalayas, to say nothing of the Rocky Mountains and the White Mountains, is expected to have on hand a full store of virgin ecstacy. All stock expressions of admiration are in keeping here,...

BERLIN, Aug. 23.--The North German Gazette, in a leading article on M. Gambetta's utterances at Cherbourg on the 9th inst., points out that the declarations of President Grevy and M. de Freycinet, at Dijon and Montauban, afford most welcome and satistactory assurance that the speech of M. Gambetta must not be taken as expressing the opinion of the country, but merely of M. Gambetta himself.

NEWPORT, Aug. 21.--It is 100 years ago. Thames-street presents a gala appearance. Groups of officers with magnificent white uniforms and costly side-arms burnished in gold and precious stones move up the street. Peals of laughter rise in the air, and only the occasional roll of a drum and the never-ending quivive from the endless line of sentinels tells of war.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. 1880. The receipts from internal revenue to-day were $749,946 56, and from Customs $737,130 55. The President has recognized Benjamin C. Clark as Consul of the Republic of Hayti at Boston.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Aug. 23.--The Coronor's inquiry into the May's Landing collision was continued this morning. The testimony of the three witnesses in relation to the three additional deaths was heard. In the case of Henry McCann, the physician, at the Pennsylvania Hospital stated that death had been facilitated by liquor brought to the patient by his friends.

The signal of a flagman, acted upon at the same time by the engineers of two distinct trains, at an early hour yesterday morning, in a depot-yard near the Long Branch station, brought about a collision on the Long Branch Division of the Central Railroad of New-Jersey. Four men were severely injured by it, and a number of cars were wrecked.

BOSTON, Aug. 23.--The several nominating conventions, State and Congressional, here in Massachusetts begin with September--the Democratic on the first day of that month, the Prohibitory on the 8th, the Greenback on the 22d, and the Republican on the 15th--and with them the campaign publicly opens. What may be termed the preliminary campaign has not been especially spirited.
The Republican Party of this State is, fortunately, able to regard with perfect equanimity the discussion of the question as to whether a State Convention should be held this year or not.

LONDON, Aug. 23.--A supplement to the Mark-Lane Express tabulates 348 reports from the agricultural districts. They show that wheat is be low the average, barley above, oats and beans a little above, and peas a little below. The results of the second hay harvest will probably make up for the deficiency of the first cut.

The committee appointed at a meeting held under the auspices of the Christian Temperance Brotherhood, at the Rink, on Sunday, to wait on the Excise Commissioners, and present them with resolutions commending their course in reference to the enforcement of the Excise law, called at Police Head-quarters yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23.--Rear-Admiral Howell, commanding the United States naval force on the European Station, reports to the Secretary of the Navy, under date of Gravesend, Aug. 8, as follows: "The Trenton is still at this port, and I purpose to remain here for a few days more before sailing for Southampton. It is my purpose to return to the Mediterranean in the latter part of this month.

At the State election in Arkansas, which is to be held on the 6th of next month, an amendment of the Constitution is to be submitted to a popular vote, which is a virtual repudiation of nearly the whole debt of the State. The proposed method of effecting this result is something unique. The amendment, which received the approval of the...

The following appears in the Rochestor Democrat and Chronicle; "George Furman, a well-to-do and reputable farmer, lives in Penfield. With his wife and son he retired for the night last Friday at about 11 o'clock. About 4 o'clock Saturday morning Mrs. Furman was awakened by a singular noise, and aroused her husband.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 23.--James Thorp, a workman in the Missouri Pacific Railroad machine shop, had a quarrel yesterday with Alfred Perry, colored, and, after the latter had made, or attempted to make, an assault on him, killed the negro almost instantly. Thorp was arrested.

LONDON, Aug. 23.--The Hon. William E. Forster, Chief Secretary for Ireland, replying to an inquiry in the House of Commons to-day, stated that the Government do not think it necessary to ask for exceptional powers for the preservation of peace and the protection of life and property in Ireland. They do not know, he said, whether they can rely during...

Another escaped Texas steer--though not, it is believed, one of those brought here to fight with Spaniards in the up-town arena--afforded West Side residents in Ninth-avenue considerable amusement and excitement yesterday afternoon.

The case of the insurance broker, Elijah Alliger, came up for a hearing before Justice Smith, in the Tombs Police Court, yesterday. There was a large number of persons interested in the case present in the examination-room in the morning. Among them were Messrs. Owen O'Connor, Francis Sherwood, Merritt Trimble, and Mr. Jordan, Cashier of the Third National Bank.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Aug. 23.--Fifty people, constituting nine families, residing in nine pleasant, handsome little houses in Plains, a surburban village of this city, are anxiously and prayerfully waiting for the end, and hoping that the exterior signs that their houses will go down into the bowels of the earth may not be fulfilled. Beneath this village the Delaware and Hudson Company...

Every one is familiar with the story of the astute monkey who, having lost his tail in circumstances which were far from creditable to him, insisted that no monkey of any self-respect would be guilty of wearing a tail. He told his fellow-monkeys that they knew perfectly well that tails were useless and ugly, and that in delaying to boldly throw their tails away they were exhibiting cowardice and insincerity.
The first matinee performance of "The Tourists" will be given this afternoon at the Fifth-Avenue Theatre.

The report of Commissioner Campbell, of the Department of Public Works, for the quarter ending June 30, 1880, was transmitted to Mayor Cooper yesterday. It shows that the amount expended during the period was $729,645.35, and that the total outlay for the six months ending June 30 was $1,201,262.34.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24.--Reports received from Collector Brayton, of South Carolina, by the Internal Revenue Bureau, recall efforts made by the bureau in 1877 and 1878 to suppress illicit distilling in that State. Collector Brayton telegraphs that revenue officers destroyed an illicit distillery 25 miles from Greenville on the 22d inst., and that the officers while at work were fired upon from ambush.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 24.--The case of Dr. Philip A. Bissell, of Mahanoy City, who was arrested for writing a letter, said to be obscene; to the city editor of the Philadelphia Record, commenting upon the Buchanan diploma case, was up before Judge Butler, of the United States Circuit Court, this morning.

The heated term promises to gladden the hearts of rural hotel-keepers and the Metropolitan ice companies for several days to come. The records in the Signal Service Bureau gave no indication last evening of an early diminution in the temperature.

M.L. Goldman's dry-goods store, at No. 61 Canal-street, was entered by burglars last New Year's morning and about $6,000 worth of silks, satins, , were stolen. The thieves entered the store by digging a hole through a side wall in an adjoining alleyway, through which one of them ...

ST. PAUL, Aug. 24.--The Democratic Congressional Convention in the Second Minnesota District is to be held at Le Sueur tomorrow. This district has been represented for the last two years by Henry Poehler, a Democrat, though it gave nearly 5,000 majority for the Republican candidate in 1876.

The Republican State Committee of NewJersey held its first meeting in the readingroom of the Hotel Hudson, (formerly Taylor's Hotel,) Jersey City, yesterday afternoon, the session beginning at 12:30. The committee is composed of 18 members, and the complete list is as follows:
A meeting of the colored Republican Central Committee will be held at Science Hall, No. 141 Eighth-street, this evening.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 24.--For several days vague rumors have prevailed here that a correspondence was going on between two well-known citizens which might culminate in a hostile meeting, but last evening it was reported that the correspondence had ended in an amicable adjustment of the difference.

PANAMA, Aug. 16.--The Government of Costa Rica has formally protested against "the validity of the contract for the construction of an interoceanic canal, which was concluded in Managua on May 25 last." It will not consent to such a document, not because the material interests of the country would suffer by the completion of the work, but ...

BOSTON, Aug. 24.--From the large number of arrivals to-day, the indications are most favorable for a successful meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, which will hold its annual meeting at the Institute of Technology, in this city, beginning to-morrow.

Silas Lewman, aged 75 years, committed suicide at his home, near Prather Station, in Utica Township, nine miles from Jeffersonville, Ind., on Thursday afternoon, by shooting himself through the head with a shot-gun. For 56 years Silas Lewman pursued the vocation of a farmer in Clark County. He attended strictly to business, was sober, honest, and industrious.

LONDON, Aug. 24.--An official dispatch dated Kandahar, Aug. 21, says: "The sortie of the 16th inst. against a village on the east face of the city has secured us from further molestation on that side, but our loss was heavy. Several officers were killed and several severely wounded. Lieut. Maclaine, who has been missing since the battle of Kushk-i-Nakhud, is a prisoner in Ayoob's hands.

The sixth and final game of the base-ball tournament series which began on Wednesday, Aug. 18, on the Union Grounds, in Brooklyn, between the Nationals, of Washington; the Unions, of Brooklyn, and the Rochesters, terminated yesterday, with the Rochester men ahead, the Nationals second, and the Unions third, the latter failing ...

SARATOGA, Aug. 24.--The weather was very sultry this morning and the clouds gathered ominously, but they were soon broken into rifts before the time for starting for the track had arrived, and the ladies ventured to see the sport in large numbers, as they have done every day during the season, especially when the programme promises brilliant racing, as it did to-day.

The Republican State Committee met yesterday and nominated Charles J. Folger for Chief-Judge of the Court of Appeals, deciding, after discussion, not to waste time and money by calling a State Convention. The degree of interest felt throughout the State in the political contest may be in some measure understood from the fact that, upon the call for the meeting of the committee, 31 out of 33 members responded in person or by proxy.
QUEBEC, Aug. 24.--The steamer Cybele, ashore on Anticosti, is much broken and will be a total loss. The passengers have been taken to Gaspe by the tug Janet M.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24.--The leading Bourbon organ in this city published a statement some time ago in which were given the names of three men living near Columbus, Ind., who had gone over to Hancock from the Republican Party. These cases were used to support the assertion that many Republicans in Indiana were doing the same.

It has been a matter of speculation to visitors at the Democratic national head-quarters, as to what Mr. W.H Barnum and the other members of the committee who are reported to frequent the upper chambers of the house No. 138 Fifth-avenue, have been doing since the National Committee met at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel to organize.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24.--The editor of the Washington Post has been to Maine, and he writes to his paper a very discouraging letter about the campaign in that State. He has discovered that the Greenbackers have nearly all the candidates, while the Democrats are expected to cast nearly all the votes.

Yesterday evening another chapter in the era of blood was added by the Rance brothersHenri, Fernand, and Armand--when they mercilessly slew Edwin C. Mix, Jr., at the corner of Kerleree and St. Claude streets. The animus existing between the parties, according to the purported statement of the Rance brothers, involves their sister, a charming young lady.

At a meeting of the Board of Health yesterday, two complaints were received against the Union Market Building. One, that the ceilings were in a dangerous condition and liable to fall at any moment, was referred to the Controller.

Gen. Albert J. Myer, the head and front of the Signal Service in the United States, who for 22 years rendered invaluable service to the country in observing and reporting approaching changes in the weather, died in Buffalo, yesterday, in the fifty-second year of his age.

Politics in the State of Massachusetts are always peculiarly interesting on account of the general intelligence and independence of her citizens. Nowhere has conviction in regard to principle a stronger, and mere allegiance to party a weaker, hold upon the people than in that old Commonwealth.

Judge Charles J. Folger, the Republican candidate for Chief-Judge of the Court of Appeals, was born in Massachusetts, April 16, 1818. A sweepstakes yacht-race for a purse of $25 will take place from the foot of Thirty-seventhstreet, South Brooklyn, to-morrow at noon. The race is open to all open sloops 22 feet long.
Perhaps the ingenuity which is being displayed in hunting up the cases of alleged Republican converts to the Democracy in Indiana and elsewhere might be more profitably employed.

The hearing in the case of the accused insurance broker, Elijah Alliger, in the Tombs Police Court, before Justice Smith, consumed the entire day yesterday. The action of the Republican State Committee yesterday in nominating Justice FOLGER to the vacant seat of the Chief-Judge in the Court of Appeals will meet with general approval throughout the State.

The hot weather may make political work uncomfortable, but it does not relax the industry of the Republicans at the National Committee head-quarters. Interest centres in Maine, New-Hampshire, and Vermont, as the campaign has been pushed very sharply in those States.

The Commissioners of Police and Excise of Brooklyn passed a resolution on the 10th Inst. increasing the liquor license fee from $100 to $250. Acting in accordance with a decision made by Judge Barnard, they also resolved not to grant any more licenses for ale and beer alone.

The past decade has been a period of remarkable constitutional growth in all countries now enjoying a representative form of government. Every year extends and confirms the sway of organic law and gives fresh proofs of its beneficence.
DECATUR, Ala., Aug. 24.--Gen. Joseph E. Wheeler was nominated yesterday for Congress by the Democratic Convention of the Eighth District.
LONDON, Aug. 24.--The Attorney-General has consented to the Tichborne writ of error being submitted to the House of Lords, the appellant's solicitor having given adequate reasons.

The receipts to-day from internal revenue were $271,849 29, and from Customs, $677,294 16. The Postmaster-General to-day directed that the name of the Post Office at West Meriden, Conn., be changed to Meriden, Conn. Mr. Edwin D. Hall, who has been Postmaster at West Meriden for some time, is continued as Postmaster at Meriden.

NEW-LONDON, Aug. 24.--The glory of this place is its elms. There are hundreds of them--tall, stately trees, some more than a century old, with stout, bulging trunks, and wide-spread, far-reaching limbs, from which depend thick, green masses of foliage that sway and rustle pleasantly in the breeze.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 24.--The Directors of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company have just issued their statement of the business of all the lines of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company east of Pittsburg and Erie for July, 1880, as compared with the same month in 1879, which shows an increase in net earnings of $302,890.

CONSTANTINOPLE, Aug. 24.--Mr. Goschen, the British Ambassador, has communicated to the Porte a telegram from the British Consul at Scutari, announcing that the Albanians are preparing to resist the surrender of territory to Montenegro. The diplomatic body at Constantinople are convinced of the sincerity of the Porte in offering to cede Dulcigno, but doubt its ability to do so.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24.--The following changes in the stations and duties of officers of the Adjutant-General's Department have been announced : Lieut.-Col. Chauncey McKeever has been relieved from duty at the head-quarters of the Military Division of the Atlantic and Department of the East, and will report in person to the Adjutant-General for assignment to duty in his office.

Medical men are fond of finding in some one particular cause the origin of all the evils to which the race is subject. ST. LOUIS, Aug. 24.--Several more divisions and lodges of Knights of Pythias arrived this morning, and were escorted to their quarters by local lodges. All the hotels are handsomely decorated with flags and the colors of the different divisions. Fourth and Fifth streets and Washington-avenue ...

LONDON, Aug. 25.--A dispatch from Vienna says: "The article of the North Gernan Gazette, commenting on M. Gambetta's utterances at Cherbourg, caused a sensation here. Its firm but moderate language is generally approved."

The failure of Loeb Co., exporters and importers at Nos. 121 and 123 Franklin-street, which was made known yesterday, has caused much surprise in trade circles. Bradstreet's reports say the firm had a branch house in London and sales offices in Manchester, ...
Some time ago Mrs. Alice Grower, of No. 4 Hamilton-street, got married and bought some furniture on the "installment" plan of Henry S. Eisler, of No. 81 Bowery.

The Democratic Congressional contests are at present exciting considerable interest. The conventions of the First and Fifth Districts meet less than two weeks hence. The fight on the Eastern shore is amusing.

The Commissioners of the Sinking Fund were occupied for nearly an hour yesterday in considering the report of the Fire Department that Fulton Market was in an unsafe and dangerous condition, and should be demolished.
Among the prisoners in the First District Police Court, in Jersey City, yesterday morning, was Peter Ackerman, of No. 227 Fifth-street, who was charged with having been drunk and disorderly.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 25.--The creditors of Archbishop Purcell have called a meeting to prepare a statement of their grievances to send to Rome, with the hope of interesting the Pope in behalf of the diocesan debt of $3,500,000.
ST. PAUL, Aug. 25.--Austin, Mower County, this State, was the scene of an attempt at political assassination last night, better suited to the latitude of Mississippi than that of Minnesota.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 25.--Mr. Thomas Hughes, member of Parliament, and party arrived her a from New-York this morning. They are the guests of Mr. Frankiln W. Smith, of Boston. They will leave here for the West in a few days.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, Aug. 25.--The first bale of new cotton from Alabama to this market was sold at the Cotton Exchange to-day for 18 cents a pound. It came from Decatur, Ala.
SPRING VALLEY, Aug. 25.--A very large meeting of the Republicans of this town and vicinity was held here to-night to ratify the the nomination of Glarfield and Arthur.

LONDON, Aug. 25.--A dispatch from Kandahar says: "The enemy is making no attempts at a regular siege. Gen. Brooke, whose death was previously reported, was shot during the late sortie from that city, while attempting to bring in Capt. Cruickshanks, who was wounded."

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., Aug. 25.--Fully 35,000 persons were congregated in the camp-meeting grounds when the morning services commenced in the large auditorium. This was the largest assemblage of the season, nearly 8,000 of them being pleasure-seekers. At 9 o'clock rain began to fall, and continued falling until nightfall.

The abilities of the cat as a cheap, domestic electrical machine have long been known. The ancients were familiar with the beautiful experiment of taking a cat into a dark room and rubbing her fur the wrong way, whereby she gives forth sparks and bad language.

We noticed recently the accounts given in Russian newspapers of the mischief which is being done by locusts. One of the most destructive insects in South Russia is the beetle called by naturalists Anisoplia Austriaca, and by the rural population ...

A writer on the London Telegraph who has spent a morning in the "Zoo" moralizes as follows on the character of the elephant: "Nor, when we speak loftily of the elephant's 'docility.' should we forget that the measure of this virtue may be gauged by the individual's capacities for the reverse.
Although there is an ancient maxim to the effect that exchange is no robbery, the adage is obviously intended to be understood with several important limitations.

The sloop-yacht Intrepid, while on her way from Newport for New-York, was struck by a squall off Hart Island, at 1:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon upset and sunk in 20 fathoms of water. Everything was lost, the crew themselves barely escaping. The yacht was of 9 tons burden, and owned by Mr. Roger M. Sherman, the lawyer of this City.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25.--The United States Steamer Alliance arrived at Halifax yesterday, and will leave for Portsmouth, N. H., as soon as coaled. The Tallapoosa arrived at the League Island Navy yard at 2:30 yesterday afternoon.
Jacob Fleck, who has no home, was overcome by the heat at No. 112 West Houston-street at noon yesterday, and taken to the New-York Hospital.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 25.--As much misapprehension exists as to the time of meeting, it is officially announced that the Army of the Cumberland will hold its reunion at Toledo, Sept. 22 and 23.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 25.--A dispatch from Tucson, Arizona, yesterday, says: "Sheriff Butner, with a posse, left here last night to intercept and arrest the Mexican brigand, Reyes, ...

A group of children, among whom were Edward Chisholm, aged 8 years, and his sister Ellen, aged 20 months, of No. 482 Smith-street, Broolkyn, went to play in a vacant lot on Court-street, near a large oaken ice-box, such as is used by butchers and grocers.

LOUISVILLE, Aug. 25.--The first meeting of the editors of colored newspapers in the United States for the purpose of organizing a permanent press association, was held at Beck's Hall to-day, and was fairly attended.

Henry S. Young, the youthful clerk of St. Luke's Hospital, who was arrested on Monday on a charge of stealing from the hospital safe $250, was called for examination yesterday in the Yorkville Police Court.
The recent general order from the Headquarters of the Army announcing the new detail of field officers for recruiting service makes one or two changes and offers one or two suggestions.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 25.--The Municipal and Tax Committee of the New-Jersey Legislature is now in session here, examining the bill reported by the committee of the last Legislature regulating city and township taxation. It will report the bill, with amendments, to the next Legislature. The bill is a general one, including every city and township in New-Jersey.

An outgoing train on the New-York and New-Haven Railroad came into collision yesterday at 5 P.M., at the One Hundred and Sixty-ninthstreet crossing, with an ice wagon belonging to a man named Keller, of West Farms, and both the horses were killed. The driver remained in his seat uninjured. It is said that the accident was caused by the determination of the driver to get over the track in advance of the train.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 25.--The case of Dr. George B. Johnston, arrested on the charge of being about to engage in a duel with Capt. John S. Wise, was called in the Police Court to-day, but was continued without hearing until Saturday, owing to the absence of an important witness. Capt. Wise has not yet been arrested.

It has been established beyond a doubt that the young lady who took passage on the steamer Arizona, of the Guion Linc, on her last trip out, under the name of Miss Kate B. Caulfieid, and who committed suicide by jumping overboard while the steamer was in the Irish Channel, belongs to a highly respectable family in Brooklyn.

It looked very much like "old times" yesterday morning in the Seventh and Thirteenth Wards. There were probably not so many diamonds or so much costly raiment displayed as when Tweed reigned in his glory in that neighborhood, but everybody was just as happy, and just as eager for a day's enjoyment.

Mrs. Catharine Ryder, the woman whose daughter, Mary F. Patterson, ran away from home and married a blind news-dealer named MeCombor, applied to Justice Murray, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday, for a warrant for the arrest of her daughter and her husband on a charge of perjury.

Yesterday began with every indication of another hot day--not that the thermometer was so very high, but, as on Tuesday, the air was so uncomfortably oppressive that, after any unusual exertion, it seemed almost impossible to draw a full breath.
PORTLAND, Aug. 25.--It is reported that some members of the Enforcer Prohibition Party met here to-day and nominated Joshua Nye for Governor, vice Osgood, declined.

E.H. Ludlow Co. sold at auction yesterterday, by order of William D. Shipman, Assignee, the last batch of securities and accounts belonging to the firm of Duncan, Shorman Co. The sale realized a very small sum.

The Hon. Frederick A. Potts, Republican candidate for Governor of New-Jersey, was given offcial notice yesterday of his nomination, and formally accepted the candidacy. The ceremony took place in the afternoon, at Senator Potts's Summer residence at Monmouth Beach.
LONDON, Aug. 25.--The race for the Great Ebor Handicap Stakes was run to-day at York, and was won by Mr. T. Cragg's Novice, Stockmar second, and Mr. J.B. Cookson's Coromandel II. third.
CONCORD, N.H., Aug. 25.--Gen. George B. McClellan will be at Weirs, on wednesday next, as the guest of the New-Hampshire Veteran Association at its annual reunion.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 25.--The Greenback Convention of New-Jersey met here yesterday afternoon. Joseph A. Bucher, of Newark, presided. After a prolonged discussion and much confusion, Thomas B. Hoxey was nominated as the candidate of the party for Governor.

Coroner Brady concluded the inquest yesterday in the case of Albert Mansfield, who died in Bellevue Hospital on Aug. 3 from injuries received by him when robbed and beaten by unknown persons near the corner of Spruce and Nassau streets, several weeks ago.
DETROIT, Aug. 25.--The National Convention of representatives of State Grand Councils of the Masonic Order was held in this city to-day, 21 States being represented.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 25.--Samuel W. Canfield, President of the Rockland County Savings Bank, and R.P. Eels, Secretary, who have been in prison for four months on a judgment against them of $40,000, were brought before Judge Barnard to-day, by the Sheriff of Rockland County when their counsel, in proceedings for insolvent debtors, moved for their release from confinement, and Judge Barnard granted the motion. They left here for Nyack on the noon train.

GALVESTON, Texas, Aug. 25.--A dispatch from Hearne to the News says: "The Republican State Central Committee met today and nominated E.J. Davis for Governor and A. Siemiering for Lieutenant-Governor. A full State ticket was also put in the field."
There was much rejoicing among the brewers and bear-sellers of Brooklyn yesterday over the decision of Justice Cooke, directing the Excise Commissioners to grant a beer license to Fritz Ochs.
QUEBEC, Aug. 25.--Great damage has been done to the growing crops in the township of Buckland, Bellechasse County, by hail-storms, the settlers in many instances having lost their entire crops.

ALBANY, Aug. 25.--The State Board of Audit has just disposed of the claim of Weed, Parsons Co. for Legislative printing, filed on June 8 last, and has arrived at a unanimous conclusion in respect to all the items therein contained.

A little girl, only 12 years old, was brought into the First District Police Court, in Jersey City, yesterday, by her uncle, to relate to Judge Peloubet a story of cruel treatment on the part of her mother.

Late last night a man named Dick Ring was arrested by Sheriff Robertson for an attempt at burglary. The facts are as follows: Mrs. George Sisson, a widow, who lives with her daughter and a Mrs. Crittenden, were awakened by the noise made by some one attempting to force their way into the house.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 25.--The funeral of the late Gen. Myer will take place from Dr. Pierce's Hotel Friday afternoon. The military organizations of the city, together with the United States troops stationed at Fort Porter, will act as escort.
Mr. George Holland will have a benefit at the Standard Theatre to-morrow evening, appearing in "Our Gentlemen Friends."
CINCINNATI, Aug. 25.--The deaf-mutes of America are holding here to-day their first convention.
The funeral of Sexton Isaac H. Brown, which took place from Grace Church yesterday, was attended with a degree of pomp and circumstance in keeping with the life and services of the deceased.

OTTAWA, Aug. 25.--Major Walsh, who has arrived here, says that when he left WoodMountain, on June 12, Sitting Bull was peaceable and quiet, and he was surprised to see the telegrams published in a paper yesterday from Gen. Miles. Major Walsh says Sitting Bull promised him he would place no obstacle in the way of any of his tribe who desired to return to the United States.
NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 25.--B.W. Lacy, of New-Kent County, was nominated as candidate for Congress from the Second Congressional District by the Readjuster Convention to-day.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25.--The storm of lastnight appears from telegraphic advices to have extended over a large area of country, and its effect on the corn crop will doubtless be most favorable, as the stalks were drying up very fast in some places. At this time them is every indication of further and general rains.

The death of the Rev. William Ballantyne Hodgson, Professor of Economic Science in the University of Edinburgh, is announced. Prof. Hodgson was born at Edinburgh in 1815, and educated in the high school and university of his native city.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25.--There is one question with which the people of the Northern States will be brought face to face before the end of this Presidential campaign. They will be asked if they will place every branch of the Government in the hands of men who have shown a desire and an intention to compel them to pay the war losses of the South.
The registry of applicants for membership in the new Night Medical Service was closed-last night, and Superintendent Walling received lists from all the precincts except the First and Thirtysecond.
Gen. GARFIELD has rarely appeared to better advantage than in the address made by him yesterday at the reunion of the Fortysecond Ohio Regiment, of which he was the first Colonel.
CHICAGO, Aug. 25.--The Western Division of the Republican National Committee held a protracted meeting here to-day.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 25.--Notwithstanding the storm, the polo games this afternoon were played before a fair audience. Messrs. E. Zbrowski and John Sanford played against W.C. Sanford, the Hon. John Roche, and the Hon. Charles Harbard. Six games were played, five of which were won by the first-named team.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 25.--The Republican State Convention met this morning, Col. A.R. Anderson being chosen temporary Chairman. All the counties in the State, except Palo Alto, were represented.

The colored Republican Central Committee met at Science Hall, Eighth-street, last evening. Chairman William Freeman presided. A memorial was sent to the Republican Central Committee asking the co-operation of that body in establishing a head-quarters "where the colored voters can meet and discuss the important political questions involved in the issues now before the people."
CONSTANTINOPLE, Aug. 25.--The Ambassadors still await the replies of their Governments to the offer of the Porte to cede the Dulcigno district, except Gruda and Dinosh.

A poorly clad woman, whose countenance was peculiar and her forehead extremely high, met Officer, Murray, of the Tombs Court squad, yesterday, in the corridor of the Tombs, gave her name as Margaret Clark, and said she wished to give herself up as a vagrant.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25.--Postmaster-General Key and the Hon. Horace Maynard called upon the President at the White House to-day, and while they were there the President signed Mr. Maynard's commission as Postmaster-General and delivered it to him.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 25.--A fire broke out soon after 4 o'clock this morning in the flour mill of William B. Thomas Co., at the north-west corner of Thirteenth and Willow streets.

Mr. William F. De Haas, the well-Known painter of marine pictures, and a brother of Mr. Mauritz F.H. De Haas died on the 16th of July, on board a Dutch steamer bound from the Azores to Rotterdam, Holland.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25.--Gen. Weaver, the National Greenback candidate for the Presidency, arrived in Washington to-day from his tour through Kansas and Indiana, where he has been making political speeches. He leaves to-morrow for Boston, where he is to deliver a political address at Faneuil Hall on Friday night, the 27th inst.

Sing Gee, the Chinese proprietor of a laundry at No. 122 Seventh-avenue, was a complainant before Justice Murray, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday, against a young Irishman named Sylvester Mooney, who lives next door to the laundry.

SARATOGA, Aug. 25.--The Grand Children's Carnival, which had been some time in preparation, took place to-night in the Congress Hall ball-room, which was thronged with fashionable people. The marches and manoeuvres of the children were accomplished with precision, and won many plaudits. A ball ended the festivities, in which the older people participated.
Justice Streng, of Hoboken, was awakened about midnight Tuesdasy, and on going to the window saw a man and woman standing at the door.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., Aug. 25.--Complete census returns show the population of Wisconsin to be 1,315,464. an increase since 1870 of 206.794.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 25.--At a special election here, yesterday, an ordinance providing for funding the outstanding indebtedness of the city by issuing 20-year 5 per cent. bonds was adopted, on a light vote, by 226 majority.

BOSTON, Aug. 25.--Over 200 members of the American Association for the Advancement of Science had registered their names in Boston Tuesday evening, and many more have arrived since that time.

AUGUSTA, Aug. 25.--There is danger that distance may lend enchantment, to the view of the so-called temperance movement in Maine, under the supposed leadership of Candidate. Dow but the real manipulation of one Joshua Nye.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 25.--Two meetings of the Beta Theta Pi fraternity were held to-day, and a public meeting was given to-night. The public meeting was fairly attended, and the fraternity was addressed by the Rev. O.D. Kellogg, of Philadelphia. There are present representatives from 46 Alumni Chapters, including those of New-York, Richmond, Louisville, Indianapolis, Nashville, Wheeling, Baltimore, Cincinnati, Evansville, and Chicago.

READING, Penn., Aug. 25.--This city is now almost totally without water, there being none flowing east of Seventh-street.
ST. JOHN. N.B., Aug. 25.--John Elliot, 15 years of age, while playing base-ball here yesterday, was struck in the neck by the ball and instantly killed.
The keeper of the dog pound has reported to the Mayor that 4,330 dogs have been drowned since the building was opened and 319 redeemed.
CHICAGO, Aug. 25.--A special to the Tribune from Galena says Gen. Grant arrived there at 6:30 This evening from his Western trip, and was received heartily by his Galena friends.

WESTON, West Va., Aug. 20, 1880.--To-day has been a grand day for the Republicans of West Virginia. A mass-meeting was held, at which the Democrats were invited to divide the time. First was a speech by Sturgiss, Republican nominee for Governor.

The creditors of Loeb Co., exporters and importers at No. 121 Franklin-street, whose failure was announced on Wednesday, were unable yesterday to obtain any definite information as to the standing of the firm or the cause of the failure.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Aug. 26.--About 200 deafmutes are now here attending the national convention. Very little progress in business was made today. The chief topic of discussion was in reference to the appointment of a National Executive Committee, and the subject was tabled.

The problem how to steer between cruelty in prison management, on the one hand, and that misplaced mildness which destroys the discipline and defeats the design of a prison, on the other, is continually recurring, and thus far baffles a complete solution.
CHICAGO, Aug. 26.--A bloody and possibly fatal fight occurred this morning between a man and a monkey, in a small zoological garden in State-street.

Fire was discovered soon after noon, yesterday, in the sub-cellar of the five-story building at No. 38 Vesey-street. The flames increased so rapidly that several fire alarms were sounded, and Vesey and Barclay streets were soon filled with engines and trucks, and travel was greatly impeded.

KINGSTON, Aug. 19.--A disastrous hurricane passed over this island last night. Thousands of people are houseless. Crops, fruit trees, and farm produce generally were destroyed. Huge trees were uprooted and churches demolished. The barracks in this city were destroyed. Three wharves are gone, and eight large and thirty-two small vessels are wrecked in the harbor. Famine is imminent, and help is required for the starving thousands.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 26.--Charles Frost, one of the victims of the May's Landing collision, died at the Pennsylvania Hospital last night. This is the twenty-sixth death resulting from that accident.

It seemed to be well understood by Wallstreet brokers and bankers yesterday that the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railway Company really intend to extend their road from Binghamton to Buffalo, and it was semioffcially announced that an organization will be effected to-day.

ST. JOHN, Newfoundland, Aug. 26.--The schooner Lily, from Cadiz, while sailing into St. John Harbor, came in collision with the French schooner Providence, and the latter had her main boom and mainsail carried away. The Lily sustained some slight damage to her fore rigging.

About 10 o'clock last night a fire broke out in the paper mill of Castle May, in South Lawrence, Mass., and before it could be extinguished consumed the greater portion of the building and a large amount of stock.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26.--Howard, White Crowell, of the Commercial Bulletin, have replies from correspondents in 250 counties in the North west, from Aug. 10 to the present time, as to the condition and prospects of the corn crop.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 26.--The condition of Mr. Washington McLean, editor of the Cincinnati Enquirer, greatly improved during the night. Dr. Barthelow, Mr. McLean's family physician, arrived here this morning and was greatly encouraged. To-day Mr. McLean has been thoroughly rational for the first time, and "seems himself," to use Dr. Barthelow's expression. The physician hopes he can be safely removed to his home in Cincinnati in a few days.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26.--The Democrats of Virginia and Maryland flocked into the city this evening to aid the Democrats of Washington in holding a ratification meeting.

The stakes of the Saratoga Association, which closed on the 15th of August, were made public to-day, and the large number of entries in each shows that the breeding of thoroughbreds is assuming vast proportions.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 26.--At Dan Mace's sale of trotters to-day, the horse Wilbur F., winner in the 2:36 class to-day, was sold to a Philadelphia gentleman for $3,450. The horse Governor Standiford sold for $530.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., Aug.25.--The Republicans of Monticello and vicinity met at Fulton's Hall, Saturday evening, and organized a Garfield and Arthur club.

MILFORD, Penn., Aug. 26.--The third annual clam-bake of the Fat Men's Association, embracing the Counties of Monroe, Wayne, and Pike, Penn.; Sussex County, N. J., and Orange and Sullivan Counties, N.Y., was held here to-day. There was a very large attendance. The heaviest man was Erastus H. Lewis, of Jersey City, who weighed 330 pounds. James Townsend, of Sussex County, N.J., was elected President of the Association for the ensuing year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26.--By direction of the Secretary of War, Col. Charles Sutherland. Surgeon, has been detailed to inspect certain medical and hospital property on hand at the medical purveying depot, San Francisco.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 26.--The Beta Theta Pi Fraternity closed its session this evening. The officers elected are: E.J. Brown, of Harrison, Ohio, General Secretary; R.S. Young and S.G. Williams, of Cincinnati, and Dr. W. P. Watson, of New-Jersey, members of the Board of Directors, and Major Wyllis C. Ransom, of Michigan, Visitor. The other officers are elected by the Board of Directors. The fraternity adjourned to meet in Chicago during the last week of August, 1881.

HAVANA, Aug. 26.--Tne Goverment has authorized the importation, duty free, of merchandise destined for the Exhibition at Matanzas. Such importation will only he allowed at Havana and Matanzas. Invoices must be certified by the Spanish Consul at point of shipment. If merchandise remains on the island after the Exhibition closes, full duty will be charged. All articles the importation of which is ordinarily prohibited must be reshipped after the closing of the Exhibition.

LONDON, Aug. 26.--Durham Co., merchants, of No. 2 Fen-court. Fenchurch-street, in this city, have failed. Their liabilities exceed 100,000. The firm is largely engaged in the South American and East India trade, having branches at Rio Janeiro and Colombo.

At a meeting of the British Goat Society, held yesterday at its rooms, No. 446 Straud, a letter was road from the Earl of Rosslyn accepting the office of President of the institution, and stating that his lordship would be glad to do all in his power to make the goat available for milk and other useful purposes among the poorer classes.
PROVIDENCE, Aug. 26.--The United States Signal Corps Association held their annual reunion at Rocky Point to-day, Capt. F. R. Shattuck, of Boston, presiding.

She had a large load of passengers. One hundred and thirty are reported saved. Some are known to be lost.

George C. Harward, a young and wellknown lawyer of Brooklyn, was stabbed to the heart and almost instantly killed about 2 o'clock yesterday morning during an affray on Atlantic-street, in that city. CHICAGO, Aug. 31.--Judge Burton, of Iowa, granted an injunction on Aug. 27 against the Missouri, Iowa and Nebraska Railroad Company issuing any more bonds for the extension of its road. Service was made on the company yesterday. This will block the extension of that line until Jan. 1, 1881, as, in any event, the injunction cannot be removed before that time.

This afternoon at 3 o'clock the Tammany committee chosen yesterday by Police Justice Patrick G. Duffy will visit the Westminster Hotel, where they have been invited by an Irving Hall committee to confer with them concerning a Democratic union upon the selection of Congressmen and members of Assembly.

CANTON, Ohio, Sept. 1.--Between 40,000 and 50,000 people were here to-day. The Twenty-third Regiment held a reunion in the Opera-house this morning at which President Hayes presided and made some remarks.

Simeon Gutmann Sons, manufacturers of shirts, at No. 369 Broadway, failed yesterday and made an assignment to Marx Rothschild, a brother-in-law of S. Gutmann. The failure was a great surprise to the trade.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 1.--Thomas McDonald, about 28 years old, a farmer, living near Commercial Point, Pickaway County, was taken from his house, last night, by a mob and hanged to a tree near his residence. McDonald came from Kentucky several years ago and married into a highly respectable family, owning a large farm.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Sept. 1.--The Democrats in this Congressional district to-day healed all breaches by renominating Alexander H. Stephens unanimously by acclimation. Some opposition on account of that gentleman's indorsement of Simmons's census enumerator and opposition to the appropriation riders melted away.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1.--By direction of the Secretary of War, Brig.-Gen. R.C. Drum, Adjutant-General, has been assigned, in addition to his other duties, as Acting Chief Signal Officer of the Army.
BUFFALO, Sept. 1.--The Police authorities of this city have completed a piece of work, as the result of which they believe they have broken up a gang of burglars and counterfeiters.

The ninth annual regatta of the New-Jersey Yacht Club took place yesterday over the 20mile course southward from the dock off the Elysian Fields. Of the twenty-odd boats belonging to the fleet, only four appeared to take part, and the largest of these were 30-foot sloops of class B. There was a small attendance of spectators.

PARIS, Sept. 1.--The Police found the Jesuit schools in Paris, Lille, Toulouse, Montpellier, and elsewhere, evacuated except by civil representatives. At Poitiers, however, they found six Jesuits, three of whom claimed to be proprietors.

BOSTON, Sept. 1.--Mrs. Erminnie Smith, of Jersey City, read a very interesting essay yesterday on the Iroquois language. It embraced the results of long and earnest original investigation.

On the 1st of May last Mr. AMZI HOWELL rented from Mrs. ELIZA A. STYMUS, for one year, the house known as No. 251 West Sixteenth-street, in this City. Early in June Mr. HOWELL vacated the premises without paying any rent, and the landlady thereupon sued him for $130, being the rent of the house for two months.

Two verdicts were rendered yesterday by a Coroner's jury in the case of Barney Morgan, the Staten Island teamster who disappeared from his home on the 13th ult., and whose body was found in the water off Coney Island three days afterward. Coroner Herrman held the inquest.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 1.--William Kennedy, the book-keeper charged with embezzling about $40,000 belonging to his employer, was examined before a magistrate to-day, and was held in $10,000 bail to appear for a further hearing on Sept. 15.

SYRACUSE, N.Y. Sept. 1.--Some time ago Superintendent of Public Instruction Neil Gilmour removed Prof. J.H. Hoose from the position of Principal of the Cortland Normal School. Prof. Hoose declined to give up the office, and was sustained by the local Board of Trustees.

Gaston for the head of the ticket, proved, after all, too strong, and, securing a ballot, defeated the ex-Governor, nominating ex-Congressman Charles P. Thompson, of Gloucester, instead.

BANGOR, Sept. 1.--The contest in this (the Fourth) Congressional district is sharper and more emphatically a trial of strength between the ideas that control the two parties than that in any other section of the State. This is attributable to the very aggressive and radical character of party leaders in the Penobscot Valley, and especially to the personal characteristics of the present campaign.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 1.--Gen. Garfield is passing a busy Summer in the midst of serene quiet. A telegraph wire runs from Mentor railroad station to his residence, and an operator who resides there is kept measurably busy with the large amount of campaign business that has to be transacted under Gen. Garfield's direct supervision.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 2.--The annual report of the St. Paul, Minneapolis and Manitoba Railroad shows the following figures: Total earnings for the year ended June 30, 1880, $2,933,108, an increase of $1,032,570 over 1879; operating expenses, $1,300,512; land sales, $597,672; miles of road owned and operated, 656; miles of new road built during the year, 98; miles of road relaid with steel rails, 101.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2.--It was announced to-day that justice had at last been done to W. L. Springs, of South Carolina. A telegram was received from E.M. Brayton, Collector of Internal Revenue, saying that Springs, after serving as a convict in the ponitentiary for two years, had been pardoned.

A report reached Police Head-quarters from an unofficial source last night that a gentleman guest at a fashionable hotel had been assaulted by highwaymen in front of a resort in East Houston-street late on Wednesday night, and that he had been badly beaten and robbed of a valuable gold watch.

LONDON, Sept. 2.--The Viceroy of India, telegraphs that Gen. Stewart's rear guard arrived at Dacia on Wednesday, (yesterday.) The reports from Kabul say that all is well there. The Ameer is assiduous in personally conducting public business.

RALEIGH, Sept. 1.--The census returns of this State have not been "doctored" to the same extent that those of South Carolina have. Two of the Supervisors were Republicans, and it was impossible to carry out the Democratic programme in their districts.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2--Postmaster-General Maynard said to-night, in responding to a serenade tendered him by the Tennessee Republican Association, that when he left the United States its people were struggling with depression of trade, with crippled commerce, and financial embarrassments.

The Chicago, Burlington and Quincy and Hannibal and St. Joseph Railroad Companies formally signed a new traffic agreement, covering the business between Kansas City and Chicago, in the Brunswick Hotel late on Wednesday night.

The Fall meeting of the Coney Island Jockey Club will be opened to-morrow on the Sheepshead Bay course. The plans for beautifying the new course are so extensive that it will take the work of another year to complete them, but much has been done during the Summer toward the great improvements which are to make the course the most attractive as well as the most extensive in the country.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Sept. 2.--The examination in the case of Peter M. Baum, charged with malpractice in obtaining a decree of divorce for Maria Antoinette Simmons, was resumed before Referee Charles Herrick this morning. The first witness called was an aged gentleman named Henry H. Couklin, of Red Hook, who has been a business man in Red Hook many years.
LONDON, Sept. 2.--The Republique Francaise says: "We decline to believe that the Ministry can have anything to do with the letter of the religious congregations.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 2.--The Republican State Convention was called to order at 1 o'clock to-day in the State-house by R.B. Elliot, Chairman of the State Committee. E.W.M. Mackey was elected temporary Chairman and Major Noah Secretary.

The Westminster Hotel was again thronged yesterday by war-like Democrats who nudged each other in the interests of peace and harmony in the party. The lottery of Wednesday, by which the Assembly districts were wildly scattered among the factions, was discussed with more earnestness than pleasure by the Tammany and Irving Hall politicians, who are now supposed to be in happy partnership in a glorious cause.

Landseer was an artist so popular, both in England and the United States, that the incidents of his life are of peculiar interest to us. As far back as his grandfather, John Landseer, who was a jeweler in London in 1701, the artistic element had existed in the family. John Landseer, Sir Edwin's father, was an engraver of merit, who was one of the founders of the London Artists' Fund.

BERNE, Sept. 2.--The American killed by the overturning of the diligence at Schuls was Edward Bearing, of Now-York. He was seated on top of the diligence when the accident happened, and was frightfully crushed.

TUCKAHOE, N.Y., Aug. 31.--One of the largest Republican meetings ever held in this place was addressed by I.N. Mills, of Mount Vernon, and James S. Young, of Tuckahoe, last night.

NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 2.--At the meeting of the National Board of Steam Navigation today, a letter was read from Surgeon-General Hamilton, United States Marine Hospital Service, urging the passage of a law compelling the examination of all seamen before shipment. It further suggested the establishment of a National Snug Harbor for worthy seamen and officers who are permanently disabled.

The second day of the lawn-tennis tournament, at Camp Washington, Staten Island, opened pleasantly yesterday afternoon. There was a larger number of spectators present, and more interest was taken by outsiders than the day before, probably for the reason that they understood the game better after the previous day's experience.

Ward's new steam-ship, the Newport, started on her first trip for Havana shortly after 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon. There was a large crowed at the dock, Pier No. 16 East River, to witness her departure.

LONDON, Sept. 2.--A Berlin dispatch says: "It is understood that the naval demonstration in Turkish waters will begin on the 15th inst. It is calculated that by that time all the vessels detailed for the service will be able to reach Ragusa."

Great concern is expressed in a wide circle of admirers respecting the condition of the Rev. Dr. Edwin H. Chapin, who has been confined to his house with serious indisposition since his return from Europe, four weeks ago.

CARAMELS, I.--(Cheap caramels for children.)-- One cupful of water, one of sugar, one-half cupful of grated chocolate, and a piece of butter the size of a walnut; boil the water; sugar and butter to a syrup, and add the chocolate when nearly done; stir to prevent lumping; spread on greased paper, and cut into squares.

Yesterday a rude flint arrow-head was found in a cave near the Delaware Water Gap. Primeval man had drawn his bowstring, launched his shaft, and the quivering arrow, missing its quarry, had buried itself in the clay wall of the cave. Some year or more ago, Prof. Curtius, working at Olympia, exposed to the light of day a glorious statue of Hermes; the work may be of Praxiteles.

A policeman who stopped him was unable to obtain satisfactory answers to his questions, and he took the lad to the station-house. Later in the day he was sent to the office of Chief Murphy, who questioned him closely.

The long cloaks worn last Winter are not likely to be in general use next season. There is much to be said in their favor, but they have some disadvantages. These cloaks completely cover the dress, and are consequently very economical, as old skirts can be worn under them.

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, Sept. 4.--President Hayes and party arrived at 10:45 this morning on a special train. The national salute of 38 guns was fired. Over half the population was present at the depot and greeted the party with deafening cheers. Mayor Adams tendered the President the hospitality of the city in a few remarks.

PARIS, Aug. 23.--Who is Maud Branscombe? Her portrait is in every photographic shop-window. Sometimes she is a nun, her eyes raised toward heaven in fervent ecstasy; in another place she appears as an odalisque, with her yashmak drawn aside and her beautiful brow glittering with rows of sequins; elsewhere we see her dressed as a fine lady of the nineteenth century, and yet again as Ophelia or the Magdalen.
Capt. Thomas McLean, Ordnance Officer on Gen. E.L. Molineux's staff, Eleventh Brigade, Brooklyn has resigned.

EASTON, Penn., Sept. 4.--The campaign in Northampton County is just fairly opened. This is principally an agricultural region, consequently the farmers have been too busy with their crops to give much attention to politics.

--The coppersmiths are just as busy, and rather more noisy; the open shops are crowded with men, some knocking the pots into shape, others engraving, some eating, others idling, while the front of the shop is choked with vessels for sale; and outside, on the ground, one or two men are occupied in cutting out different patterns from copper sheets.

CONSTANTINOPLE, Sept. 4.--The line of Montenegrin frontier proposed by Turkey starts from the Gulf of Castrati, leaves Malakash to Turkey, thence bends westward, and, after passing between Dinoschi and Podgoritza, leaves Kutchikiajna to Montenegro.

LACKAWAXEN, Penn., Sept. 3.--Some time ago there appeared in THE TIMES a very interesting account of the aspect of things legal and political in Pike County, Penn. The first impression likely to be produced by that article would be one of incredulity that there could be found within four hours from New-York a community in so rude and primitive a condition.

HAVANA, Sept. 1.--The steam-ship City of Merida has arrived here from Vera Cruz, bringing dates from the City of Mexico to Aug. 24. On Aug. 20 the first preliminary session of the Tenth Congress was dissolved immediately upon opening, after fixing the 24th for a new preliminary session.

The first of a series of games between the New-York and Brooklyn nines was played on the Union Grounds, yesterday, in the presence of a large assemblage. The contest proved to be one of the most exciting played in this locality during the season, and 10 innings were necessary to decide it, as the score at the end of the ninth stood 4 to 4.

A letter to a leading English journal recounts the many shortcomings of British cookery. Fault is found with the construction not only of the salad but of the salad-bowl. In a French service there is always two salad-bowls, a large and a small one, each adapted to the number of people who are to partake of the salad.

In his "Heart of Mid-Lothian," Sir Walter Scott tells of the serious opposition to tho proposition to supersede the old easy going fly-coach by the rapid mail-coach encountered in England and parts of Scotland in the seventeenth century. It was alleged that accidents would be more frequent, and that the movements of the mail-coaches would be so rapid that passengers would not have time to dispute the charges of the inn-keepers.

PORTLAND, Oregon, Aug. 24.--The political campaign causes a serious interest here, but there is little excitement since the June election has shown how firmly the State is Republican. A Republican majority was expected, but not one of so decided a character.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 5.--The British steamer American, which arrived at this port yesterday, from Kingston, Jamaica, brings papers containing details of the terrible cyclone which swept over that island on Aug. 18. Capt. Wallace, of the American, describes the destruction as complete.

MATTEAWAN, N.J., Sept. 6.--James Malloney, 27 years old, living at Hightstown, was struck by the night freight train due here at 12:30 A.M. MILFORD, Penn., Sept. 7.--The trial of James K. Bortree for the murder of Henry W. Shouse, at Honesdale, Penn., on the evening of July 15 last, has been deferred until Dec. 7, a further hearing having been granted. The trial was to have commenced at Honesdale to-day. Bortree, the murderer, was a farmer, and resided at Ledgedale, Wayne County.

A gratifying indication of the prosperous condition of business was made known yesterday at the meeting of the Dock Commissioners.
