LONDON, Sept. 8.--An explosion occurred this morning in the Seaham Colliery, near Durham. Both shafts of the mine are blocked, though they are half a mile apart. It is believed that 180 men are in the pit, and that most of them have perished. It is known that 17 of them are safe.

Dr. J.B. Taylor, Chief of the Vaccinating Bureau, has prepared a report on the appearance of small-pox at No. 109 East One Hundred and Ninth-street. He says that at present he has been unable to place tho responsibility for the spread of the disease where it belongs.

At the meeting of the Bayonne (N.J.) Common Council Tuesday evening the Board granted to the Standard Oil Company, whose works are at Constable Hook, the privilege of laying an oil pipe through a section of Thirtieth-street, in that city.
RICHMOND, Sept. 21.--It has always been assumed by the best informed politicians of both parties that the negro vote of the South was unalterably attached to the Republican organization.
The one hundredth anniversary of the capture of Major John Andre by the three American soldiers--Paulding, williams, and Van Wart--is to be celebrated with appropriate ceremonies at Tarrytown to-day.
The Memphis (Tenn.) Appeal of Sept. 17 calls the Northern people "canting hypocrites" whose "impudence" is sublime.

The publications of this country are chiefly issued in this City and in Boston. The latter city is not a little restive over its literary position, but it is inevitable that literary men should more and more gather within reach of the great publishing-houses, and these will always be chiefly in New-York.

Senator BLAINE has long had the reputation of being one of the most skillful political organizers and managers in the country. Whatever else may have been thought of him, his eminence in this particular has been generally acknowledged.

The pawn shop of Meided Meyer, No. 528 Second-avenue, was broken into on the night of the 30th of April last by a gang of expert and daring burglars, the large safe in the place was torn open, and property consisting chiefly of watches and jewelry, valued at $4,709, was carried off.
The First Ward Garfield and Arthur Campaign Club will hold a meeting to-night at No. 4 Morris-street.
Now that Gen. B.F. BUTLER has joined himself again to the Democratic Party, there is no valid reason for the continued existence of the "Greenback-Labor Party" of Massachusetts.

The registration of pupils of the evening schools was begun on Monday last, and will continue for two weeks from that day. City Superintendent Jasper says all persons who desire to avail themselves of the advantages of the schools should register at once, as that will experience some difficulty in doing so after the schools are once opened. on Oct. 4.

An important question respecting the validity of the marriage abroad of a citizen who, while traveling, has maintained his domicile here, has been finally determined by the Court of Appeals in the suit of Mary Eliza Hynes and William H. Secor, as guardian additem of Mrs. Hynes's two children, against Kate McDermott, Mary J. McCreery, and Lavinia Gay.

PARIS, Sept. 22.--A telegram from Ragusa says: "The Montenegrin commandant at Podgoritza has imprisoned the principal Mohammedan inhabitants. This bas greatly irritated the Albanians, and increases the difficulty of surrendering Dulcigno."

BRATTLEBORO, Vt., Sept. 22.--The telegram announcing the arrest at Omaha of the defaulter, S.M. Waite, late President of the First National Bank of this place, created excitement only equaled by the first news of his defalcation and flight last June.

Mr. Marcellus Hartley, the senior member of the firm of Hartley Graham, dealers in guns and military goods, at Nos. 17 and 19 Maiden-lane, on arrving at the store earlier than usual last Saturday morning, noticed James Burns, the porter employed by the firm, loading upon a truck drawn up to the sidewalk six large bundles of wood consisting of broken-up packing cases.

CONCORD, N.H., Sept. 22.--The Democratic Convention of the Second Congressional District to-day nominated Alvah W. Sulloway by acclamation. Frank A. McKean, of Nashua, was nominated as candidate for Elector.

The interior of the Metropolitan Concert Hall, at Broadway and Forty-first-street, looked like a beautiful garden last evening, when the regular Autumn exhibition of the New-York Horticultural Society was opened.
The entries for this the second day of the extra meeting at Sheepshead Bay indicate another rare day's sport for those who take an interest in horse-racing.

The examination in the case of Mr. Charles B. Helfenstein, the Broadway jeweler, who is charged with having drawn a pistol upon Mrs. Jennie Martin and threatening to shoot her while in her room at No. 357 West Thirty-fourth-street on Monday night, was resumed before Justice Smith, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday.
A very quiet but elegant wedding attracted a handful of the representatives of New-York society to Oakdale, Long Island, yesterday.

The uses of homeopathy are without number, and its cures are as wonderful, if not as miraculous, as those effected by the tincture of Knock mortar. Seldom has there been a medical discovery made of more importance to the human race than that recently made by Dr. Ginery, of Boston, and it is the latest and most wonderful of the triumphs of homeopathy.

The New-York Rifle Club has practically absorbed the field formerly occupied by the Amateur Rifle Club. It Started as a short-range organization, and has done more to develop the sport of that class than any other club.

WORCESTER, Sept. 22.--The Greenback Convention which was held in Horticultural Hall to-day consisted of about 200 delegates, among whom was one woman.
Police Justice Nelson K. Wheeler died of heart disease on Tuesday night at his farm in Deposit, Delaware County, N.Y.

The failure of Isaac Elkus, wholesale dealer in clothing at No. 538 Broadway, who made an assignment yesterday to Julius Levine, caused much surprise in the trade, as he had met his bills promptly up to Wednesday, and had always enjoyed a good reputation in the course of 35 years in business.

Those who attended the high mass of requiem in St. Paul's Church, East. One hundred and Seventeenth-street, yesterday morning, for the repose of the soul of the late Judge James P. Sinnott, learned that rather Eugene Maguire, the Pastor of that church, is a master of the art of vituperation.
The Burlington (Iowa) Hawk-Eye prints the following letter, addressed to its editor:

GARNERVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 22.--A rousing Republican meeting was held in this Rockland County town last night. A Garfield and Arthur campaign club was organized, and 110 members signed the roll. The following officers were elected: James E. West, President; H.M. Peck and C. Y. Wemple, with nine others, Vice-Presidents; J.H. Jones, Recording Secretary; J.D. Norris, Corresponding Secretary; H.B. Hargreaves, Treasurer.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 22.--Jesse Grant, the third son of Gen. U.S. Grant, and Miss Lizzie Chapman, daughter of W.S. Chapman, of San Francisco, were married last night at the Palace Hotel, in this city. There was no great display, although the apartment in which the nuptial knot was tied was handsomely decorated with flowers.

SARATOGA, Sept. 22.--Previous to the opening of the business meeting of the Unitarian Conference, this morning, a prayer-meeting was held, led by the Rev. C.A. Staples, of Providence, at which brief addresses were made by the Rev. W. H. Charming, of London; the Rev. J.H. Hayward, of Louisville; James Freeman Clarke, of Boston, and the Rev. Robert Collyer, of New-York.

Ex-Alderman William R. Roberts, Chairman of the Tammany Hall sub-committee, sent a communication last evening to the Irving Hall committee renewing Tammany's proposition for a joint conference on Saturday, at 4 o'clock in the afternoon, Mr. Roberts states that the Tammany committee was not prepared to hold a conference on Friday.

HAVANA, Sept. 18.--A royal decree, published in the Madrid Gazette on Aug. 26, disposing of the Government bonds issued on this island in February, 1873, in compliance with a decree of Aug. 9, 1872, has had an alarming effect upon the holders of these bonds, who are thus deprived of more than one-half of the capital invested in them.

Capt. J.H. Allers, the pilot who brought the Cunard steam-ship Scythia into port on Tuesday evening, brings news of a wreck which is floating bottom upward, several hundred miles off the coast, with the corpses of her crew still in her cabin and forecastle.

There was a rousing meeting of the Garfield and Arthur Club of the Thirteenth Assembly District in their club rooms, Eighteenth-street and Eighth-avenue, last evening. The elegant and commodious rooms, finished in natural woods and illuminated with massive chandeliers, were packed to overflowing.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22.--The delegates to the Pan Presbyterian Alliance meeting had a brilliant social reception this evening at the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts.

DENVER, Col., Sept. 23.--At Las Vegas yesterday afternoon, Samuel Matthews, while under the influence of liquor, killed his girl and committed suicide. No cause for the act is assigned.

PARIS, Sept. 23.--The decrees appointing the new Ministers have been gazetted. The papers of all shades of opinion agree that the appointment of M. Barthelemy-St. Hilaire as Minister of Foreign Affairs is a guarantee of a pacific policy.

QUEENSTOWN, Sept. 23.--Two Liverpool tugs arrived at Roche's Point, at 1:30 o'clock this morning, and proceeded to the assistance of the steamer City of Chester, which arrived off Roche's Point about 11 o'clock this morning.

Rupert is in jail at Lima.

WHEELING, West Va., Oct. 26.--The Baltimore, Cincinnati and Western Railroad Company was incorporated in this city to-day, with a capital of $5,000,000. The incorporators are Cincinnati and Baltimore capitalists. Ex-Gov. Thomas Young, of Ohio, will be President. The road will run from Cincinnati to Ironton, Ohio, thence across West Virginia to Virginia and Maryland and on to Baltimore, a distance of 600 miles.

Clubb, President and Superintendent of the Wiggins Ferry Company, Receiver of the Keokuk Northern Line Packet Company. The bond was fixed at $200,000. LONG BRANCH, N.J., Oct. 28.--During the absence of the widow of Edwin Adams, the actor, at Boston a few days ago, her sea-side cottage at this place was broken into by burglars who carried away everything of value. The Police have no clue to the robbers.

BUFFALO, N.Y. Oct. 28.--At the great Republican mass-meeting held here this afternoon, which was addressed by Senator Conkling, Gen. Grant presided. On being presented by the Hon. Sherman S. Rogers, the applause was long and deafening, and it was several minutes before order could be restored.

Dr. Edward Seguin, the celebrated specialist in the treatment of idiocy and allied nervous diseases, died yesterday at his residence, No. 41 west Twentieth-street, in the sixty-ninth year of his age. CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 28.--Many in quiries have been received here to-night to know whether Gen. Garfield is still at his home in Mentor. He is, and in answer to a telegraphed inquiry relative to a subpoena for him to appear in New-York, he replied that he had heard of no such document.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 28.--One hundred and eighty United States Supervisors of Election were appointed to-day by Judge Treat, of the United States court. One hundred and twenty-five Deputy Marshals, appointed by Marshal Caste, were approved by the court. Other Supervisors and Deputy Marshals, enough to furnish two of each to each of the 244 voting precincts in the city, will be appointed between now and Monday.
The seventh annual meeting of the Westchester County Historical Society was held yesterday at White Plains. Mr. James Wood, President of the society, occupied the chair.

To give an impulse to tho education of parrots, a bird-show has been held at the Alexandra Palace. Professedly, the object of the display was to encourage aviculture generally, but from what we are told, it would almost seem as if the whole affair had been got up as a parrots' benefit.

FORTRESS MONROE, VIRGINIA, Oct. 28.--While the crews of the fleet were engaged in competitive drill, shifting sail, yesterday, an ordinary seaman named Daniel Clairy, on the Alliance, missed his footing and fell to the deck, striking upon his head and fracturing his skull, from the effects of which he died this morning. He will be buried at the Hampden National Cemetery this afternoon with appropriate honors.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 28.--The Direstors of the Cincinnati, Hamilton and Dayton Railroad Company to-day declared a divident of 2 per cent. on the capital stock of $3,500,000 out of the earnings for the six months ending Sept. 30. The gross earnings for the six months were $1,473,482, and the net earnings $105,340, leaving a balance after paying the dividend of $35,340.

Grow delivered a sound political speech, and was frequently interrupted by applause. He spoke for over two hours, holding the audience until the end. SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 9.--The Bulletin this evening publishes a letter from a trustworthy correspondent at Tientsin, China, in which is given the substance of an interview between the Chinese Grand Secretary of State, Li Hung Chang, and Mr. Seward, late Minister of the United States in China.

Mlle. Bernhardt spent yesterday quietly, after the fatigues of her first night. At breakfast she had all the morning papers brought to her, and amused herself in scanning the mass of criticisms contained therein. She declared herself more than satisfied with the nature of her reception, and was especially pleased with the generally kindly and respectful tenor of the comments.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9.--The Cabinet meeting to-day was brief. Immediately after the adjournment all the members present, excepting Secretary Sherman, took carriages at the Executive Mansion and drove to the wharf, where they boarded the United States steamer Dispatch and proceeded to Hampton Roads to witness the naval review to-morrow.

A fire was discovered shortly after 6 o'clock yesterday morning on the third floor of the fivestory brick building extending from No. 313 to No. 323 East Twenty-second-street, and adjoining the Eighteenth Precinct Police Station. The building has a frontage of 150 feet, a depth of 75 feet, and was occupied by a large number of manufacturers. It was filled with immense quantities of inflammable material.

LONDON, Nov. 9.--The inauguration of the Lord Mayor of London took place today. The route of the procession was profusely decorated with flags. The new Lord Mayor gave the customary banquet in Guildhall to-night. Nearly 1,000 guests attended. Mr. Gladstone, M. Challemel-Lacour, the French Ambassador, and Mr. Condastaulos, the Greek Minister, were received with enthusiastic cheers. Mr. Lowell, the American Minitser, was present.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9.--The double-leaded editorial in the New-York World of to-day, charging that the records of the various departments of the Government here were recently overhauled by "unofficial persons," under instructions from the chiefs of the several departments during their absence, is the most silly effort to produce a sensation that has been made for many years.

SCRANTON, Penn., Nov. 10.--A mysterious case of forgery, which has divided public opinion in this county for more than a year, culminated this morning in the court of Susquehanna County, at Montrose, where the defendant, Robert Enbody, had it removed, as he feared he could not receive justice in Scranton because of the excited condition of popular sentiment.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10.--A large number of applications from officers of the Army and other persons have been filed at the War Department for appointment to the office of Chief Signal Officer of the Army, made vacant by the death of Gen. Myer.

At a meeting of the Pilot Commissioners yesterday, a communication was received from Health Officer Smith, complaining that masters of vessels are in the habit of taking their departure, with the concurrence of the pilots in Quarantine, before his arrival. NEW-GLASGOW, Nova Scotia, Nov. 16.--All day yesterday men were at work filling in the main shaft with spruce and clay sods to stop the passage of air into the mine. The overdue steam-ship Bristol, of the Great Western Line, was sighted off Fire Island at 2:30 yesterday afternoon. She will probably be towed up to the City to-day. The Gloucester, of the same line, which left seven days after the Bristol sailed from the port of that name, arrived early yesterday morning, and her officers were greatly surprised at the non-arrival of the other vessel.

The new six-story brick building on the South-west corner of the Bowery and Hester-street was destroyed by fire yesterday, involving a loss of $93,000. From what the fire originated has not yet been definitely ascertained.

Not only was yesterday the coldest day this season, it was the coldest of the year, with only one exception. On the 2d of February last the thermometer ran down to 17 , (average for the day,) and that was the only day in 1880 that was as cold as yesterday. It was stinging cold and windy, and there was no keeping warm out of doors without being well scrapped up.

Mr. L.H. Trechette, the Canadian poet laureate, was given a dinner by a large number of the leading citizens of Quebec on the evening of the 17th inst. Judge Henry Taschereau, a near relative of the Archbishop of Quebec, presided. The usual loyal toasts were drunk with honors, and then a toast to France was proposed and was responded to by the Consul-General, M. Lefaivre.

On Sunday last the Rev. STEPHEN H. TYNG, JR. preached a sermon in which he is said to have distinctly asserted that miraculous cures have been performed at Lourdes and at Knock. He said of Lourdes: "No one dares attempt to deny that multitudes of cures took place there. The lame leaped, the deaf heard, the blind saw. It will never do in this generation to deny those wellauthenticated facts."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22.--The annual report of United States Treasurer Gilfillan, showing the transactions of his office and the condition of the public business during the fiscal year 1880 was submitted to Secretary Sherman to-day. It appears that the receipts compare favorably with those of the previous year, and show an increase from Customs, internal revenue, and sales of public lands of $59,811,505.78, and a decrease in those from miscellaneous sources of only $112,079.26.

LONDON, Nov. 13.--The Autumn Cabinet councils have commenced, and as two have been held within a week it may be fairly presumed that the Government have serious work on hand. The question of immediate importance is the condition of Ireland, and whether there will or will not be an Autumn session.

A rather curious difficulty is just now troubling the French Army. In every nation where the liability to service in the ranks is obligatory, a proportion of the youth of the country is allowed to free itself from the regular service as private soldiers by becoming "one-year volunteers." The volunteers have to pass examinations and bear a considerable portion of their own charges.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 3.--In the Third Ward to-day the Registers struck the names of three women from the registry, the women protesting. The women referred to came to the Republican City Convention this afternoon, and asked the privilege of the floor. A motion to grant it to them was not seconded, and they left the building.

PROVINCETOWN, Mass., Dec. 3.--The funeral of Capt. David H. Atkins, Elisha N. Taylor, and S. Frank Mayo, of Life-saving Station No. 7, who were drowned on Tuesday morning, took place to-day in the Centre Church, the Rev. H. Martin officiating.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 3.--Marie Roze took a farewell benefit to-night here, in "Carmen." The house was crowded with the best people of Philadelphia. There was not a vacant seat in the entire house. The performance was a great success. Marie Roze will leave here for Chicago in the morning.

PETERSBURG, Va., Dec. 3.--A correspondent, writing from Wilson, Grayson County, Va., reports that diphtheria has recently prevailed, in a very malignant form, in that county. In some families five and six persons died, and in one instance the whole family died, not one escaping.

KNOXVILLE, Tean., Dec. 3.--During a fight to-day at the works on the Cranberry Railroad, Pooton Sooy, of this place, killed a man named Stilling. Five shots were fired, all taking effect. A woman was the cause of the difficulty.
The Grand Jury before adjourning yesterday handed in two presentments, one of which complained of the unhealthful and unclean condition of the General Sessions Court building.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Dec. 3.--Two cars and the locomotive of a Pennsylvania Railroad train were thrown from the track last night by the turning of the wrong switch while running through the yard of the New-York and Long Branch Railroad. No one was hurt and the damage to the train was slight.

Three more European steam-ships arrived yesterday. One of them, the Bath City, from Bristol, had a very long and tempestuous voyage. Police Officer John H. Stoker, of the Ninth Precinct, was placed on trial in the General Sessions yesterday, on a charge of felonious assault with intent to kill. The peculiar marital troubles of Richard C. Fellows, a lawyer of this City, have for a long time occupied the attention of the Court of Common Pleas. SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 9.--A few days ago a Mexican named Clodomero Cota was arrested under extradition on the charge of felony. The court reports published during 1880 have brought an unusual number of curious copyright cases. One fact developed by them is that what may be copyrighted is not very clearly understood. The law, both English and American, is probably somewhat old-fashioned; has not quite kept pace with the new forms and varieties in which intellectual labor is constantly produced.

The overdue steam-ships Volmer and Victoria both arrived yesterday, the former being in tow of the latter. WASHINGTON, Dec. 9.--A petition for the enactment of an international copyright law has been introduced in the House and referred to the Committee of Ways and Means. NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 9.--The following is the report of the cotton crop made by the Cotton Exchange, and based upon 82 replies from 32 counties in North Carolina and Virginia: Thirty-seven replies show the weather has been favorable from Nov. 1 to 15, and unfavorable from Nov. 15 to 30.

LONDON, Ontario, Dec. 9.--Allen, one of the burglars arrested here a week ago, pleaded guilty to-day to the charge of burglary brought against him, and was sentenced to 14 years in the penitentiary. His companion, White, alias Curtis, pleaded not guilty, and will stand his trial at the Assizes.

Schroder for the killing of Dr. Albert Lefevre was ended to-day by a verdict of acquittal, after the jury had been locked up for three days and three nights. The last two months have been somewhat notable for unusual volcanic activity at various points on the earth's surface. On the evening of Nov. 4 an earthquake shock was experienced in this city and vicinity. It was very brief in duration, but it was also one of the sharpest felt here in many years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22, 1880. The Secretary of the Treasury to-day re ceived from an unknown person, in an envelope post-marked New-York, the sum of $110. The money has been deposited in the Treasury on account of conscience.

Brewster Co. sued for the price of a carriage bought of them by Mr. Hatch, and also for payment for repairs to the vehicle.

DRESDEN, Nov. 20.--The soldiers whom the Landgrave of Hesse Cassel and the other German Princes had let out to England for the suppression of the American rebellion were brought together, in great measure, by the recruiting system. Some alterations had, it is true, been introduced into this system in Cassel by the adoption of a new plan similar to that of Prussia.

It is not improbable that if it had not been for the disgraceful occurrence in the House on Tuesday the Refunding bill would have passed that body yesterday. So much time was taken up by motions, amendments, and speeches on the subject of the outrageous scene of the day before, that no business demanding any serious consideration could be brought forward.

OIL CITY, Penn., Dec. 21.--On Saturday afternoon last the wife of R.E. Bell, Cashier of the firm of Curtis Boyle, iron-dealers, of sharon, Penn., called at the office with her little girl, expecting to accompany her husband home. He was not in at the time, and after waiting a few minutes Mrs. Bell arose to go out.

The final performance of "La Favorita" for this season at the Academy of Music last night was so good as to deserve the very highest praise. The spirit and vigor with which the opera was begun promised great results, and there was no disappointment. Miss Cary has never been in better voice, and never gave a stronger or a more thrilling performance.
PARIS, DEC. 22.--Heavy floods are reported in the Department of Calvados. Several towns and villages are inundated. In the neighborhood of Caen houses have fallen in. The damage is considerable.

About one mile south of the village of Hempstead, Long Island, is situated an estate known as the "Brick Farm." It is so called after its former owner, whose name was Brick, and who, singularly enough, was an inventor and dealer in a certnin kind of fire-brick. The farm consists of 210 acres, and it is one of the finest on the south side of Long Island.

The Executive Committee of the United States International Commission for the World's Fair of 1883, met at No. 317 Broadway yesterday afternoon. W.L. Strong, the Chairman of the committee, resigned his office some three weeks ago, but it was only yesterday that it was accepted. At the meeting yesterday Mr. Samuel A. Haines, Vice-Chairman, presided.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22.--After a desultory debate of two hours to-day, the Weaver-Sparks fracas, which disgraced yesterday's proceedings of the House, was settled in the usual manner, and apologies having been made by the two offending members, the House, by a yea and nay. vote, tabled the entire matter, thus declaring that the brief apologies uttered were a full atonement for the unusual outrage ...

St. Lous, Dec. 22.--The failure of Nauson, Bartholow Co. yesterday caused a panicky feeling on 'Change, and the opening of the Grain Board to-day was looked forward to with serious apprehension by a majority of the members of the Merchants' Exchange. As the day wore on, and corn and wheat advanced slowly but steadily as compared with yesterday's quotations, a feeling of confidence dissipated the nervousness of the morning ...

Yesterday afternoon a consultation of leading members of the Democratic County organization was had in Irving Hall. Police Justice Maurice J. Power presided. The matter before the meeting was the operation of the new plan of organization which was initiated at the election district primaries on Tuesday evening. Each of the 24 Assem bly districts were represented, and the report from each was that the plan had worked to the entire satisfaction of all interested.

The storm of Tuesday at Long Branch, which was described in dispatches from that place as "the most terrible since 1836," was a comparatively mild affair after all. Though the sea ran high and the wind and snow continued from Monday night until Tuesday afternoon, there was very little damage done compared with that caused by the great storm of February, 1880, and the Winter gales of previous years.

LONDON, Dec. 22.--A land meeting was held at Derrygonelly to-day, and was protected by a strong force of Police and infantry. Opposition on the part of the Orangemen was abandoned, but some fighting occurred after the meeting.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22.--Judge Blodgett this morning passed sentence on John G. Wustun, Orin C. Whitney, and Charles H. Perkins, guilty of defrauding the Government in the celebrated match bond cases. Each received one year, with hard labor, in the Chester Penitentiary.
ATHENS, Dec. 22.--Premier Coumoundouros has sent a circular to the representatives of Greece abroad instructing them to decline the proposal for European arbitration if it is offered.

Prof. Thomas Davidson, of Boston, a distinguished archeologist, who has lately returned from Greece, lectured last evening at Chickering Hall, under the auspices of the American Geographical Society, on the "Recent Excavations and Discoveries at Athens and Olympia."

LINCOLNTON, N.C., Dec. 23.--The mixed passenger and freight train on the Western Division of the North Carolina Central which left this place yesterday afternoon at 2 o'clock was wrecked at Indian Creek Trestle, three and a half miles west of this place, with fearful results.

A dispatch from London announces the fact that Mrs. Cross, (George Eliot,) the distinguished novelist, died at 10 o'clock Wednesday night. Her death was quiet, and almost painless. Mrs. Cross was seized with a sudden chill, which attacked her in the larynx on Sunday last.

There will be a festival in the Wilson Industrial School this afternoon. The members of the Cotton Exchange have subscribed $1,200 to the hospital fund.

The funeral of the Rev. Theodore Irving, LL. D., who died on Monday at the age of 73, took place at the Church of the Holy Trinity at 11:30 yesterday. A catafalque of ivy, smilax, and other verdure, studded with groups of roses, was erected in front of the altar railing, and upon this the coffin rested while the obsequies were in progress.

The "red ball," the signal of skating, was hoisted in Central Park yesterday morning for the first time in two years. The welcome news took the skating population rather by surprise, the recent storm and variable weather having prepared them for a different result.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 23.--The programme of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, so to delay the trains of the new line between New-York and Washington as to practically destroy competition is still being most actively carried out. The steam-ship Edith Godden, which arrived from Montego Bay yesterday, brought the news of the loss of the British bark Fontabella with eight lives near the entrance of the harbor of Falmouth, Jamaica, during the night of Dec. 10.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Dec. 23.--A fatal accident, horrible in its completeness, occurred on the Schuykill Valley Branch of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad, a few miles from this place, between 7 and 8 o'clock this evening.

The Hon. John C. New, of Indiana, is ill, being threatened with typhoid fever. Harry Parsons, a professional sword-swallower, fatally injured himself while performing the feat in Cleveland, Ohio, on Monday.

Albert Speyers, the broker who acted as the agent of Smith, Gould, Martin Co., and of Belden, Heath Co., in the enormous speculations which culminated in the Black Friday of 1869, died on Tuesday last at his country residence in Bayside, Monmouth County, N.J., of cancer of the stomach, his illness having been long and painful.

KINGSTON, Jan. 2.--A fire broke out here at about 3:30 o'clock this afternoon, resulting in the destruction of much property. It started in the rear of the upper story of a large brick building known as Military Hall, situated on North Frontstreet, and owned by Anthony Benson. By a recent decision in the United States Supreme Court the town of Litchfield, Ill., escapes payment for its fifty-thousand-dollar water-works, and the holders of its bonds issued for the works have to bear the cost, while the people of the town enjoy all the benefits of them.

HARRISBURG, Jan. 2.--Unusual interest attends the organization of the Legislature on account of the bearing it may have on the choice of a United States Senator, and since Friday a large number of the leading Republicans of the State have been here in the interest of Mr. Grow or opposed to him.

An attempt made on Saturday evening to rob the store of A.P. Rockwell, at No. 731 Broadway, was frustrated by a burglar alarm, and one of the supposed burglars is in custody. Mr. Rockwell occupies the ground and second floors and the basement of the building, and his stock of furs is valued at over $20,000.

This ingenious and artistic little work is, in substance, a comparison of Jesus with Buddha and Socrates. Although the writer devoutly adores the first, and accords to him a divine pre-eminence, yet he is very far from disparaging the others.

CORK, Jan. 2.--A party of men have visited the house of a man named Daniels and shot him, inflicting a dangerous wound. The affair is believed to be connected with Fenianism.

READING, Jan. 2.--The Belleman Church war, which resulted recently in the arrest of 19 prominent citizens of Centre Township, this county, culminated to-day in a serious disturbance and scene of great excitement at the church, which is 12 miles north-west from this city.

DRESDEN, Dec. 11.--There is not much to remind the present inhabitant of New-York of the little city that 104 years ago lay at the south end of Manhattan Island. It was a pretty place, with streets lined with trees. Before the war there had been over 20,000 inhabitants, but many of these had fled at the approach of the British forces.

The Trustees of the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge Company held their monthly meeting in the office of the company, in Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon, with President Henry C. Murphy in the chair. Twelve Trustees were present, including Ludwig Semler, Brooklyn's new Controller.

The ice-bridge has formed, and this morning seemed strong enough for any weight. The packing of the ice has given a thickness in some places of 7 or 8 feet, but the average thickness may be set down at 2 feet 6 inches, though the roadways will be much thicker than that.

Mr. PENDLETON, it is said, intends to urge his bill giving to heads of departments seats in each house of Congress, with the right to participate in debate on the business of their offices, and imposing on them the duty of answering questions which may be addressed to them on like subjects.

The Brooklyn Board of Aldermen met for the first time in 1881 yesterday, and selected Alderman Black, of the Fourth Ward, Chairman. Mr. Black is a Domocrat, and received the votes of the 13 Democrats in the board.

DUBLIN, Jan. 3.--On the resumption of the State trials this morning, the court was crowded, though the proceedings were very uninteresting, simply consisting of the reading of stenographer's notes of speeches by the traversers.
The Municipal Society met last evening and installed the officers recently elected for the present year.

Sheriff Van Rensselaer and his Under Sheriff, Col. Davis, erected yesterday, in the corridor of the Essex County Jail, the gallows on which Mrs. Margaret Meferhoeffer and her paramour, Frank Lammens, are to be handed on Thursday.

The oracle of the incoming national Administration has spoken. The paper "founded by HORACE GREELEY," which was wont to teem, in other days, with exclamations--in big type--"The Tribune is not an organ!" appeals to the American people to bear witness that it is an organ; or, at least, it is willing to be.

The two most novel and interesting features of Miss Mary Anderson's current engagement at the Fifth-Avenue Theatre--an engagement that has been quite prosperous and will end on Saturday night--are the revivals of Sheridan Knowles's "Love" and Talfourd's "lon."

The Family Circle Dancing Club took entire possession of the upper portion of Delmonico's last night, and seldom has that famous establishment been the scene of a so grand gathering of the representatives of the first society of New-York.

NASHVILLE, Jan. 3.--The Republicans scored the first victory of the session of the forty-second General Assembly to-day by electing a member of their party--W.B. Ramsey-- Speaker of the House by a majority of one.

Notice is given in another column of the dissolution of the copartnership of Campbell, Hall Co., after a prosperous existence of more than 25 years. John H. Hall retires and Augustine Smith and Richard L. Campbell continue the business under the firm name of Campbell Smith.
